titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day. Drew towards the close of Mr: Luzac’s Oration, which next week I hope to finish. Turn’d a stanza of Rousseau’s Ode to Fortune into English, and also a Cantata.

2. Return’d to Boston this morning, with Dexter— Day at My Office— Received letters, from Mr: King, and my brother; and duplicates from Mr: Williams and Bird Savage and Bird— Read Montaigne in the afternoon. Evening
at home, reading, the second volume of Robertson’s history of America.

3. Dr: Tufts called at my Office this forenoon. Wrote a letter to Mr: Gore, and enclosed to him Mr: Pickman’s bill on S. Williams— Went to see the Steam Engine at the Card Manufactory, near the Mill Bridge— Walk this morning upon West-Boston Bridge, and towards Evening in the Mall— Rest of the Evening, reading to the ladies at home— They were invited to Mrs: Storer’s, but being neither of them well, did not go— Mrs: Adams was seized very violently again, at Night, just as she was going to bed.— Her illness however did not continue so long as usual.

4. Mrs: Adams better— Court of Common Pleas sat, to make up their Judgments— Attended a short time— Recd: a letter from Mr: Williams in London, with the last protested bill taken up by him— That drawn in favr: of my brother— Wrote immediately to Mr: Pickman— Copied some other letters at home— Saw Mr: Pickman afterwards on the Exchange, and delivered him my letter— He promised to send me the bill for £1020 to-morrow.— Afternoon at my Office— Finished reading 2d. Vol: Montaigne’s Essays— Evening at the Club, at Mr: Smith’s— Mr: Freeman there. He has just moved to Newtown, and keeps lodgings in town; so that he returns to the Club— Mr: Shaw dined out of town and did not return at Night.

5. Attended at a meeting of the Trustees of Hopkins’s donation— It was the annual meeting on the first Thursday in May— At the Academy’s room in the State House. Chose Mr: Storer again Treasurer— Fill’d two vacancies at the board— Mr: Holmes the Minister at Cambridge, and Judge Davis— President Willard submitted certain queries, which were referred to a Committee, to report at the adjournment on the 2d: of June, at 12. o’clock.— Dined at Mr: T. Perkins’s—20 gentlemen— It rained in the afternoon, and Mr S. Cobb brought me home— Read Robertson, to the Ladies.

6. Mr: W. Pickman brought me from his brother a bill on S. Williams, London, in my favour for £1020 at fifteen days sight; for which I gave my note at 90 days— Exchange at 2 1/2 per cent advance. I inclosed this bill with the former one to Mr: Williams, under cover to Mr: Gore, and Mr: Shaw put the letter into the bag of the Columbine, bound to Liverpool.— Had some little business to do; this forenoon— Afternoon again at the Office. Walk in the Mall— Evening at home Reading Robertson. Finished the fourth book, containing the philosophical review of the State of the American Savages, at the discovery of the New Hemisphere— We had a thunder storm again this morning— And in the afternoon a cold North-West Wind.

7. Spent the forenoon at my Office— Mr: Gardner called on me— I went out with him in the afternoon, as far as Milton— Just after leaving him, Dexter who had been to Boston, with the Chaise overtook me, and brought me the rest of the way.

8. Heard Mr: Ware— He and Mr: Cranch dined with us— We had a considerable fall of snow, in the course of the day— Mr: Ware is going to New-York— I Finished transcribing Luzac’s Oration de Socrate Cive, and made a short poetical translation from J. B. Rousseau— What to go upon next I know not—

9. Return’d to Boston this morning, and pass’d the day at my Office— Read Harrison’s Chancery in the morning, and Montaigne in the afternoon— Mr: Quincy called on me— Mr: and Mrs: Smith spent an hour with us in the evening— During the remainder I read Robertson— The Account of Cortes, and his conquest of Mexico— Mr: Shaw this evening unwell.

10. Mr: W. Bartlett from Newbury-Port called upon me this morning.— He is likewise a sufferer by the failure of the house of Bird, Savage and Bird— Wrote to my brother and to Coll: Smith, on this subject.— In the afternoon, Deputies from the New Catholic Church called upon me— And the young man from the West-Indies— Evening, continued reading Robertson.

11. Went to Cambridge this morning, and attended the examination of the Sophomore Class. I set out to walk— But was overtaken on the Bridge, by Doctor Howard and Judge Davis in a Carriage; and I went up, and returned home with them— The Class were examined in the latin,—Livy and Horace—In Greek—The Memorabilia Socratis—in Mathematics—Watt’s Logic—Locke on the Understanding—Stuart on the Mind; Roman History—And Geography— The Mathematical examination was the most unsuccessful— The Class is very large—58 in number— At the Conclusion of the examination I address’d them in a few words of approbation, and of exhortation— President Willard was so unwell that he retired very early, and Dr: Tappan was not able to dine with us, and sent an excuse— Mr: Fiske was the only member from the Committee of Overseers who attended, except myself— And Dr: Howard and Judge Davis were the only members of the Corporation— The performance begun at 9 in the morning; and with the exception of an hour at dinner, continued untill past 7. in the evening— Thus was accomplished the last act of my senatorial duty, as a member of the Legislature of Massachusetts— After returning home, I attended the club at Dr: Spooner’s— Caroline and W. Shaw pass’d the evening at Mr: Quincy’s— The Election for Members of the House of Representatives took place in Boston this day— The members of the last year were re-elected— With Mr: W. Smith, and J. Phillips to supply the vacancies, occasioned by the election of Mr: Jones to the Senate, and by Mr: Jos: Russell’s declining.

12. Meeting of the Proprietors of Neponsit Bridge, at Whitcomb’s—to choose a treasurer instead of Mr: Miller, who resigns— J. H. Foster chosen.— Some other business transacted.— My Mother came to town this forenoon; and spent the night here— She dined at Mr: Smith’s, and pass’d the Evening at Mr: Otis’s.— Walk towards Evening in the Mall— Continued to read Robertson— Mrs: Adams suddenly very ill again; just after supper— Sent for Dr: Welsh.— Her illness was however chiefly removed before he came.

13. Mrs: Adams better, but very weak— My mother dined with us, and in the afternoon returned to Quincy— I pass’d the day, writing and copying letters— In the Evening finished the second and began the third volume of Robertsons America.

14. Writing and copying this forenoon— Sent a triplicate of my letters to Mr: Williams and Mr: Gore with Mr: Pickman’s two bills— To go by the John Adams, to Liverpool— This afternoon I walked out to Quincy. It took me three hours and ten minutes from my own door, to my father’s.

15. Heard Mr: Willard the librarian of Harvard College; who dined with us— Pass’d the leisurely part of the day in looking up the life of Pascal— Wrote nothing— Towards Evening, went with my father to the Common, where they are splitting up rocks in a new but very simple manner, for the State Prison— This day was lost to me, in respect to my usual object of Industry.

16. Return’d to town early this morning. Attended at the Office of the Commissioners of Bankruptcy, and declared dividends in the two cases of W. Neal and A. Blanchard. This prevented me from attending a Committee of the town on the subject of a Bank— Walk’d in the Mall this afternoon, with Dr: Eustis— Evening at home, and concluded the fifth Book of Robertson’s History of America.

17. Meeting of the Commissioners of Bankruptcy, for a dividend in the case of W. P. Smith— Adjourned to the 24th: instt: Met the Committee, of the town, to settle with the Agents from the County of Norfolk, upon their claim in the Old State-House— Also with the Committee to consider and report whether the town should take an interest in the proposed new bank.— Agreed upon a report in the negative; but to reserve a right of subscription hereafter— The Directors of Neponsit-Bridge had a meeting likewise, to settle the Accounts of their former Treasurer Mr: Miller, and take the bond of Mr: Foster the new Treasurer; to whom I afterwards administered the Oath— Afternoon at my Office— Evening at home, and read Robertson— Caroline very ill— Dr: Welsh here to see her— My neighbour Mr: John Codman died this afternoon at about 5 o’clock, after an illness of very few days.

18. Mr: Gardner called at my Office this forenoon; and dined with us. Afternoon chiefly lost. Walk in the Mall— Evening at Club at Dr: Warren’s— We were Galvaniz’d— Came upon the Doctor and his family, unexpectedly.— Caroline still confined to her chamber.
19. Somewhat unwell.— At my Office only a small part of the day— In the afternoon I attended Mr: Codman’s funeral.— Evening at home— Concluded the 7th: book of Robertson.

20. Had a meeting of the Commissioners of Bankruptcy, for a dividend in the case of Patrick Phillips. Read Montaigne this afternoon, and continued Robertson in the Evening.— Caroline is recovering but has not yet left her chamber.

21. Mr: Isaac Smith called on me this morning, and offered me a place to go out with him to Quincy, which I accepted— Met Dexter in Dorchester coming for me— Found our family at dinner— Mr Smith in the afternoon went to Mr: Cranch’s— I pass’d it in looking up the life of Pascal— The day fine and warm, like Spring— The first such of the Season— Walk over the hills in the Evening.

22. Heard Mr: Smith for Mr: Whitney. He also dined with us— All the leisure of the day I employed in reading the lettres Provinciales, and in researches concerning them and their author— Wrote, but left unfinished a short account of his life.— Twas quite a Summer day—

23. Returned to Boston this morning— Stop’d at Mr. Gardner’s— And on our way, went down to look at the Neponsit-Bridge, which is proceeding rapidly— Afternoon at my Office— In the Evening, I concluded the 8th: book and third volume of Robertson’s History of America. The whole of his work published in his life time.

24. Adjourned meeting of the Commissioners, for a dividend in the case of W. P. Smith— They agreed to postpone the question they had for discussion, untill the second dividend— Meeting of the Academy of Arts & Sciences. Annual choice of Officers— All those of the last year re-elected.— There were various Communications. Dined at Judge Davis’s, with several of the members— My father who was quite unwell, returned home this afternoon.— In the Evening I read part of the 9th: Book of Robertson’s History of America— The posthumous-publication.

25. Election day— Mr: H. G. Otis was chosen Speaker of the House of Representatives. General Cobb rechosen President of the Senate,— Mr: Tillinghast, Clerk to the House, and Wendell Davis, Clerk of the Senate— I went to hear Mr Puffer’s Sermon— Late dinner— At my Office in the afternoon.— Walk in the Mall, which was much crowded— Club this Evening at my house— Pretty generally attended.

26. Called this forenoon at Judge Sullivan’s, but did not find him at home— Visit to General Pinckney, who arrived last Evening in town— In the afternoon, went with the Ladies— Evening at home; and finished reading the 9th: and 10th: Books of Robertson’s History of America.

27. Forenoon at My Office— Reading of Chancery proceedings— Attended the Meeting of the Charitable Fire Society at 3. this afternoon. After attending Caroline to the church, I returned to the meeting of the Society and went in procession with them to the church— Mr: Gardner the clergyman delivered the annual address, which had too much politics, and too little of the proper subject— At tea afterwards at Mr: Welles’s. Walk’d in the Mall— Evening at home— Read the Midsummer’s Night’s Dream, to the Ladies.

28. Call’d this morning upon Mr: Sullivan and agreed to meet him to-morrow on Monday with Mr: Sigourney, at my Office, on Mr: Graves’s business.— I concluded not to go out to Quincy this day.— Judge Paine was this day chosen a Councillor, and is to resign his Office in the Supreme Court— In the Evening I read part of Much Ado about Nothing.— Henry left us.

29. Heard Mr: I. Smith in the Morning; and Mr: Marsh, a Professor of Yale College in the afternoon— The latter is a Young Man, and has a mode of delivery somewhat peculiar, but too artificial— He has some ingenuity; and apparently some taste— I wrote in the course of the day, and made some progress in compiling a life of Florian. Walk in the Mall towards Evening, and read the remainder of Much Ado about Nothing.

30. Called this morning with Mr: El: Sigourney, and his son on Mr: Sullivan, to consult upon Mr: Graves’s business— Employed the day almost entirely in examining this affair— Walk’d in the Mall this Evening, with Caroline— Read two Acts of Love’s Labour’s lost.

31. At noon I went up to the State-House, and heard the Governor deliver his speech— General Pinckney there— Executed my deed of House in Franklin-Place N: 13. to John Brazer: to be delivered to-morrow.— Saw Mr: Pickman at the State-House, and asked him, if he would receive payment of one of my notes to him— He is to answer me to-morrow— Dined at Coll: T. H. Perkins’s, with a company of Gentlemen. General Pinckney there— Evening at a tea party, at Mrs: Bartlett’s.
Day— As the last Month— Growing too indolent.
